com.ibm.team.repository.client.util

Class Event

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.util.EventObject
      • com.ibm.team.repository.client.util.Event
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IEvent, java.io.Serializable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    PropertyChangeEvent, QueryChangeEvent, QueryExecutionStateChangeEvent

    public class Event
extends java.util.EventObject
implements IEvent
    Base class for events that originate from an event source.

    To define a new type of event, a client should subclass this class, and optionally extend addCategories(List) if there is a need to classify the event under categories other then event type. However, clients may implement IEvent directly if they need to.

    Since:
    0.5
    See Also:
    IEventSource, Serialized Form

      • getEventType

        public final java.lang.String getEventType()
        Returns the type of event that has occurred. The valid types of events are defined by implementers of this class.

        Events types are unique strings that follow package naming convention.

        Specified by:
        getEventType in interface IEvent
        Returns:
        the type of event that has occurred; never null

      • getCategories

        public final java.util.List getCategories()
        Returns the non-empty list of categories for this event.

        An event listener is registered against a category, entitling it to receive notifications of events in that category. The list always includes the event's event type as returned by getEventType(), allowing client to register listeners for specific types of events.

        The Event implementation of this IEvent method computes the list of categories by calling addCategories.

        Specified by:
        getCategories in interface IEvent
        Returns:
        the non-empty list of non-null categories (element type: Object); the list is never null; the list is immutable

      • addCategories

        protected void addCategories(java.util.List categoryList)
        Adds additional categories for this event to the given list. Note that the event's event type will be included automatically, so there is no need to add it. Categories must be distinct non-null objects that can be compared with equals.

        The Event implementation of this method does nothing. Subclasses should extend this method if they have additional categories. Extended methods must call super.addCategories(categories) to include categories contributed by superclasses.

        Parameters:
        categoryList - the list of categories (element type: Object); never null
